"Be temperate in drinking, bearing in mind that wine in excess keep neither secrets nor promises"
Don Quixote to Sancho Panza

So syrah and shiraz are genetically the same grape - but the wines they produce can be very different in style, depending on origin. The typical old-world syrah is lighter and leaner than the intense shiraz wines of the new world, which tend to be richer, riper and more full-bodied. In certain areas, the name you get on the bottle - syrah or shiraz - will be an indication of style rather than where it is from.

Whatever you call it, some estimates put this as the world's fifth most planted red wine grape. Certain winegrowers in the northern Rhône distinguish between a small-berried, superior version of syrah, which they call petite syrah, and the larger-berried grosse syrah, but others reject any such distinction.

Petite sirah (with an i, not a y) is quite different, the name given to what has been shown to be a common California field blend made up variously of syrah, durif and two other varieties related to them. It makes robust, tannic, earthy wines.

France

Syrah is the great grape of the northern Rhône, responsible for the dense, burly, deep-coloured, long-lived, savoury and peppery wines of Hermitage, and the slightly more seductively perfumed (traditionally thanks to some co-fermented viognier in the blend) Côte-Rôtie. Unlike other varieties, it demonstrates a strict relationship between how severely it is pruned and how good the eventual wine is. It can also lose its aroma and acidity quickly if left past optimal ripening stage (both of which explain why so many, though by no means all, French varietal syrah vins de pays are so wishy-washy). Crozes-Hermitage is probably the best-value manifestation of syrah, although good St Joseph exists and Cornas is enjoying a revival.

Australia

Cuttings of syrah, called shiraz, were probably taken to Australia by the so-called father of Australian viticulture, James Busby, in the early 1830s. It flourished and spread, so much so that it was little treasured. Now, however, Australia has regained its pride in what is the country's most planted wine grape variety, which can taste of baked pencils in the Hunter Valley, cough syrup in the Barossa Valley (arguably its spiritual home), chocolate in McLaren Vale and black pepper in cooler parts of Victoria and New South Wales.

The great majority of Australian winemakers produce a shiraz of some sort, and many make several qualities of shiraz, as well as a range of shiraz-cabernet blends. Penfolds is arguably the past master of shiraz production - its Grange being Australia's first serious collectable. When it was made, by the late Max Schubert after a trip to Bordeaux, it was dismissed as "dry port tasting of crushed ants". In general terms, shiraz tends to taste slightly sweet and can reach high alcohol levels. Such was the success of Australian shiraz in the early years of this century that the name shiraz has been widely adopted for syrah grown in many other parts of the world.

Elsewhere

Syrah was enthusiastically planted in California in the 1990s by the so-called Rhône Rangers, who were anxious to demonstrate that it may be even better suited to California than cabernet sauvignon. Wine buyers have been less enthusiastic about it, however. There have been some notable examples in Washington state as well as in South America, particularly Chile. South African shiraz, generally from younger vines, can taste rather earthy and hot. Some of those who make the finest South African examples label them syrah. There are some notable syrahs in both Italy and Iberia, even if the grape remains a minority ingredient in the varietal makeup of vineyards there. It can also make some fine wine in sunnier spots in Switzerland's Valais.

Some of the world's best syrah is grown in the northern Rhône, where it makes dark, brooding - and expensive - wines. Chargrilled aged rib of beef rubbed with sea salt and finished with a decent slug of peppery olive oil needs wine with both muscle and structure to match. As with other full-bodied red/meat matches, dark fruit will naturally knit with the sweetness of the meat, while firm, drying tannins work to break down protein, cut through fat and clean your palate.

I am just back from spending a week on the beach in Cornwall and my wife has declared she never wants to go on holiday with me again. Caroline says this every year and the cause is always the same, namely, the fact that I don't stop working. I am that loathed and detested character: the deadbeat dad who is constantly checking his BlackBerry on the beach.

My excuse is that, as a freelance journalist, I do not receive any paid holiday. If I stop working, the money stops coming in - and my finances are so precariously balanced that simply forgoing one week's wages could bring the whole house of cards tumbling down. I suffer from what Martin Amis and Christopher Hitchens refer to as "tramp dread" - the fear that if you stop churning stuff out you won't merely fall behind on the mortgage, you'll be completely destitute by the end of the month.

Needless to say, Caroline doesn't believe this. As far as she's concerned, I'm a workaholic and "tramp dread" is just a way of rationalising my pathological compulsion.

She may have a point. Even if I won the lottery I think I'd still check my emails on the beach. The truth is, I have no desire to take a break from my day-to-day life. I don't find work stressful. On the contrary, I find not working stressful. If I'm unable to connect to the web for more than a few hours I begin to suffer from acute anxiety. For me, sitting in my car next to an internet cafe at midnight, seeing if I've got any messages on Facebook, is a way of "decompressing".

My wife isn't alone in finding this irritating. The owner of the cottage we rented just outside Helston told me that she considered putting in a wireless router, but decided against it on the grounds that most people prefer being unplugged when they're on holiday. I have no doubt this is true. Indeed, the vast majority of people are not merely uninterested in connecting to the web while on holiday - they actively despise those who do.

I can tell this by the disapproving glances I get from the other men on the beach. In the beach pecking order, a dad clutching a BlackBerry is only one up from a single man with a camera taking pictures of naked children gambolling in the surf. In their eyes, I am one of those sad, career-obsessed twats who just can't switch off.

I suspect that this is a peculiarly British prejudice. In America, there is no taboo against remaining in touch with the office. I remember being in a screening at the Sundance Film Festival a couple of years ago when the man sitting in front of me took a call on his mobile. I tapped him on the shoulder and told him to shush, but he ignored me. I tried again and this time he turned round and said, "It's my agent," as if that was a wholly satisfactory explanation. No one else in the cinema batted an eyelid.

Why do British holidaymakers find people like me so annoying? My theory is that it's part of the general prejudice against anyone who is seen to be working too hard. This, in turn, is rooted in the 19th-century distinction between those who had a private income and those who had to work for a living. The former were considered "gentlemen", while the latter were "in trade".

That may sound far-fetched, but I'm not suggesting it is a conscious form of snobbery. Like most prejudices, the taboo against working on holiday is formed by historical factors that people aren't aware of. At Cambridge, for instance, I happily used the general term of abuse "Narg" to describe anyone studying mathematics or science without knowing its implications. Only later did I discover that Narg stood for Not A Real Gentleman. On holiday, I am undoubtedly a Narg.

Who should I call for a makeover?

I recently bought a second-floor flat, and need to get it rewired and replumbed. I would also like to open up the kitchen to the living room and install a new kitchen, boiler and central heating - and I'd like it all done as green as possible. The bathroom and kitchen are at opposite ends of the flat, so routing of plumbing and wiring will be tricky. Who do I need to help me? An architect, structural engineer, separate plumber/electrician/builder? I'm baffled!

Let's separate the issues. You're not adding volume to your property or interfering with exterior or party walls, so the good news is you're not in the realm of planning permission or even permitted development. But you will have to deal with building regulations, because you're opening up between kitchen and lounge, and there are rules governing fire doors, ventilation, etc. An architect could design the layout, put the job out to tender, project manage it, and deal with any rules and regs - but they don't come cheap: expect to pay a percentage of the overall build cost (about 13% or more). For small jobs, this can be like using a sledgehammer to crack a nut (you don't want to spend £10,000 on an architect when your budget's £60,000, say).

An architect is really of use when you have no idea how to design a space. You, however, sound as if you know what you want to do. A professional builder used to jobs on this scale should be able to work from your sketches. He'll deal with any structural issues and have plumbers, joiners, electricians, etc, who work with him. You want someone who comes with a recommendation, so visit a property he's recently worked on and talk to the owner.

If the wall you're taking down is a serious structural element, you may need an engineer to design 'the steels', or supports, which will go in in its absence. But, again, the advice of a good builder is invaluable.

As for your wish to be green, well, replacing your central heating is a good start because you'll upgrade to an efficient system with condensing boiler. If your flat is in the eaves, make sure the roof is well insulated, too.

Can we save our quarry tiles?

The kitchen in our late-Victorian house has its original quarry-tiled floor - sadly covered by the previous occupants' carpet and, under that, lino glued to the tiles. We'd love to restore them. Could we do it ourselves, or would we be better off calling in a professional?

Our DIY expert, Bridget Bodoano, says, 'It's a pretty big job, and messy, but it can be done. Nigel Frost of The Floor Restoration Company (01432 851138, floor-restoration.co.uk) says first remove the remnants of lino with a strong metal scraper, then the glue, much of which can be removed with a hot-air gun (about £25, from DIY shops), which will loosen the glue. You'll need a number of scrapers and a fireproof container for the debris. Wear strong gloves (not plastic) and a chemical gas mask, because the fumes may be toxic. Ensure the room has plenty of ventilation and don't use near combustible materials. Remove any remaining glue with abrasive pads, plenty of clean cloths and, if necessary, cellulose thinners.

Next, you may find you need to re-grout. Also, if any tiles need replacing, source them from reclamation and salvage yards. Last, scrub the floor, either by hand or machine; if there is still some residue on the surface, use a strong stripper such as Selate Floor Polish Stripper (£5.50, 0845 226 7275, cleansave.co.uk). Wash well and leave to dry out for at least a week before applying a breathable sealer such as Dry-treat Stain-proof (about £40, 0800 634 8860, tf-direct.co.uk).

'If, after all that, you decide to get it done professionally, The Floor Restoration Company charges about £1,400 plus VAT for a 4m sq area.'

Jayne Fuller and Emily Sargent* were in senior creative positions in a magazine publishing house, but Fuller was going out with the boss. Sargent arrived, appearing glamorous, intelligent and altogether fabulous. Fuller felt ousted and threatened.

"I just couldn't cope with it. I felt so alienated," Fuller says. "She was the one they all loved and would turn to because she was funny and clever, whereas I was the grumpy one who everyone hated."

Sargent admits: "Jayne was the most temperamental person in the office and people pussyfooted around her because she was going out with the boss and because she was the creative director with the licence to throw toys."

Gather a group of people together, insist they spend large amounts of time in a confined space, then just sit back and watch human nature deal with the rest. The rules of Big Brother apply similarly to the office environment - still the standard backdrop of a regular working life - where we spend more time with strangers (initially) than we do with our friends and family.

Hardly surprising, then, that disputes between colleagues are integral to office life. Disputes are the meat and drink of HR departments: whole reams of employment law are devoted to them, thousands of pounds are thrown at their desired resolution - and they drive people insane.

But in the end, Fuller and Sargent sorted out the dispute themselves. Fuller says she woke up to the fact that things had to change when Sargent announced she intended to resign.

"It just hit me and I thought, 'this is insane.' So I just said to her that I was really sorry and I thought that all of the tension had been caused by the fact that I was extremely jealous of her."

Sargent says Fuller's "disarming honesty" won her over. "If it were not for the fact that one of the two conflicting parties shattered the wall of conflict I don't think it would have been resolved," says Sargent. Both are now firm friends, having left the company (and Fuller the relationship with her boss) some years ago.

Realising that the current four-year-old system of statutory dismissal and grievance procedures is costly and unwieldy, the government will, from April 2009, replace it in favour of informal mediation - that unfashionable notion of getting people to talk to each other rather than dragging everything through the courts. In February Acas - a largely government-funded organisation - was given £37m to help prevent workplace disputes unnecessarily going to employment tribunals. Acas is beefing up its advice helpline which, from next April, will point out to callers that they should try mediation as it may well be cheaper and better for all concerned. If they fail to heed this advice, Acas will conciliate at disputes that look set to become tribunals.

"By the time issues get to tribunals it's generally too late," says Mike Emmott, employee relations adviser at the Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development. The existing system of dispute resolution, he believes, requires all managers "to play every conflict by the book, watch their backs and do things that would stand up in court rather than settle the case." Once statutory rights and employment tribunals are involved, protagonists are obliged to polarise their positions in order to win a legal settlement - not exactly an outcome conducive to mutual resolution.

Emmott has just completed a how-to guide to workplace mediation, which typically involves a neutral third party or mediator bringing two opposing individuals together, encouraging them to air their views and then trying to find some mutual agreement.

It's good news for private workplace mediators and there are already calls to introduce a system of accreditation.

However, mediation is often tried too late, only after a formal grievance procedure has taken place rather than before, says Liz Hine, director of Mediation at Work. Hine recently mediated at a dispute between manager Amanda Edwards and housing support officer Jess Wilson* at a hostel for young homeless people. Wilson had already been subjected to disciplinary action which resulted in her suspension.

The nub of the problem appeared to be a personality clash between two entirely different individuals. "We're like chalk and cheese," explains Wilson. "We've got very different working practices and I just didn't feel as if she liked me very much and I suppose that got my back up. We were locking horns and never got anything sorted out."

Wilson didn't feel her suspension was warranted and thinks her manager, Edwards, was "fed a lot of gossip from colleagues which wasn't necessarily true". A protracted battle ensued which, in the end, they hammered out during a day of mediation.

"Mediation isn't going to change your whole personality," says Wilson, "the problems are still going to be there, but it's about dealing with them." It did, however, give them a space to open up honestly, with Hine acting as an impartial referee.

During mediation Edwards learned that Wilson wasn't the self-confident adversary she imagined. "Although she appears confident she doesn't feel confident," Edwards says. "We gained a better understanding of each other and I probably got a better insight into myself. One thing I learned is to nip something in the bud in the initial stages."

For mediation to work, both parties need to be both honest and constructive. "It can be quite difficult," says Wilson. "Nobody likes criticism." She thinks a few more sessions would have helped them reflect and become a bit more open. "But it has drawn a line in the sand. My relationship with Amanda is not as strained as it was."

Although better, relations are still a little raw. "I hope it settles down," says Edwards. "I think sometimes we just need to get on with our work as opposed to being concerned about whether the person we have sat next to has offered to make us a cup of tea."

Detective Chief Inspector Jackie Keddy, a Metropolitan police coach and mediator, agrees that in many cases, an honest conversation at the watercooler might avoid the march down to HR or the courts. "In most places there are shelves full of policies and protocols but it can be a case of cracking a nut with a hammer," she says. "I believe that organisations will be held accountable if they can't show that mediation has taken place and some tribunals might start to penalise them."

A little DIY goes a long way, agree primary school teachers Nigel Cullen and Sarah Thompson* who fell out over sandwiches versus hot dogs at their school fete. Eventually the two agreed to put the sandwich scenario behind them after agreeing to talk their differences through and resolve them - although Cullen insists he's going to do it his way next time.

'This is called a probe," says Lena Vakil, sweeping her hand across a tray of instruments. "That's the sort of sharp pointy thing that people are always terrified about. They ask you, 'Don't come near me with that!' But it's just to check what the teeth are like, if there's any decay or anything that's not quite right."

Leaning against the dreaded chair in her black-and-white surgical robe, Vakil's manner could not be more friendly and reassuring. I have never been very afraid of dentists to start with, and the staff at the Docklands Dental Centre in east London, all equipped with perfect smiles, are among the friendliest I have ever met. Yet there is still something undeniably macabre about this set of sterile tools laid out between us in a gleaming line. Tweezers, mirror, drill, syringe, beside which lies a tube of coloured liquid. "That's a bit more anaesthetic should we need it," she explains.

Continuing the tour, Vakil leads the way through corridors playing the kind of peaceful, tranquilising music that is only ever heard in the most terrifying places. Finally, we come to another brightly lit room with another large chair, beside which a slightly different tray is waiting. "So this is all surgical equipment," she says. "These are the scary things."

And indeed they are: scalpel holders and spare blades, needles, clamps for loosening teeth. "If someone was coming in to have an extraction," she admits, "I wouldn't show this initially." So what would she do? "We would have the same tray that you just saw there, I'd numb them up, and go through some instructions about how to look after themselves afterwards. Then wait, and everything comes out afterwards ... I think when people see the equipment they start wondering, what are you about to do to me?"

Much of the fear that still persists around dentistry is rooted in the bad old days of 30 or more years ago, when brushing was scarce, and check-ups scarcer. "People still have memories of what it was like," says Vakil, who specialises in the more complex (and potentially frightening) surgical procedures, "especially if you have parents from the time when it wasn't so advanced. They always remember these terrible stories ... Often we'll have patients who come in, and the mothers are standing there absolutely amazed that their kids are in the chair. But the kids are fine."

Advances in technology and education have brought dramatic improvements, Vakil believes, and yet dealing with her patients' nerves, as well as their teeth, is still a central part of her work. "You can tell when someone comes in," she says. "The characteristics come out. When people are anxious they can be quite aggressive ... The first thing they might say is, 'I don't like your sort.' But actually after you've treated them for some time you realise it's just because they're scared. Then you have some patients who can be very, very confident. They seem as though everything's fine. And then you realise they're absolutely terrified ... And some patients will just break down, completely."

The only thing Vakil can offer, besides a needle full with sedative, is to spend time with her patients, building up trust. For this reason, dentists often inspire remarkable loyalty in the people they treat. "[Some of] my friends travel miles to see the dentist that they saw when they were young," she says. "And I have some patients who still come over to see me from Denmark. They'll fly over and work things out so they can come and see me. And it's lovely."

What is most striking, to me at least, is to hear how seriously Vakil, and the rest of her profession by the sound of it, take the softer skills of offering reassurance while they work. The reason, she suggests, is that all dentists begin to deal with patients early in their training. After a year in the classroom, and another practising on what they call a "phantom head", all trainees are let loose (under careful supervision) on real mouths and real panics. "You learn quite early on that you've got to be able to see your patients, treat them, reassure them and do the work all at the same time," explains Vakil, with her safe-hands smile. "I think it just becomes a habit after a while."

And it was a habit she picked up even earlier than most. Her father, now retired, was himself a dentist, and as a teenager, Vakil used to go and help out around the surgery. "What I liked," she recalls wistfully, "[was] the fact that he had quite a lot of control about what he was doing ... and when I would go in on summer holidays he would be seeing the same patients again, or members of the same family, or people that were recommended to him." With her plan to follow him decided, Vakil chose a spread of maths and sciences for her A-levels, and applied to dental school, where she followed the standard four-and-a-half year course, before studying for a further two years in oral surgery, attached to a hospital.

One question has been bugging me, however, which she has not yet even touched on: why teeth? After all she could have enjoyed the variety of the whole human body as a GP, and still been working with people all day. "I found I enjoyed using my hands, doing something practical," she says. "Whereas, with general practice, you don't necessarily get the opportunity to do that. It tends to be a lot of diagnosing and that kind of work."

And now, at the age of 40, with 17 years as a qualified dentist behind her, does she notice people's teeth all the time? "I think we all do," she laughs naughtily. Has she been surveying my teeth then? "No, not at all! Not at all!" She is insistent, and I just about believe her. "I think what we do is just look at someone's mouth, make an assessment, and forget about it. It's natural."

And is she ever revolted by what she sees? There must have been some terrible mouths down the years. "I've done a lot of surgery," she reminds me. "I'd just qualified, and a person had fallen off a piece of scaffolding, straight down, and this pole had gone right up through his neck, into his skull, and missed the eye. And that was my first night on call, so I was suddenly dealing with this patient. Having had experience of seeing so many terrible things, I suppose it's prepared me quite well. So I don't think anything's too terrible."

So positive and enthusiastic is Vakil about her work, that she makes me determined to find some drawbacks. How about off-duty diagnosis? Being confronted by people and their ailments in social situations seems to be the bane of many doctors' lives. Vakil nods her head, although it is obvious that she does not mind in the slightest. "If I go to a dinner party and happen to say to someone that I'm a dentist, inevitably there will be a story from someone or the other," she grins. "And it's quite interesting. I don't know whether if you went to a party and met a lawyer you would necessarily talk to them about it." The thought gets another chuckle.

"People say, 'Oh my teeth are terrible ...'" She shakes her head frantically this time, and covers her mouth with her hand, imitating their shame. "Or, they'll launch into a whole discussion, and tell me about [their teeth] ... People do think about what's happened to them, and it'll come out one way or another. I quite like it, because it's always easy to talk about. I think it doesn't matter where you go the world over, it's exactly the same."

At last, however, we do manage to alight on something that bothers her. Although even now she is not so sure. "'Bother' is a difficult word," she says, considering the matter. "I think sometimes you can be surprised ... I [do sometimes] think, Gosh, you come and see me, and you're in terrible pain, and I know it's not a great experience for you. But we get you out of the pain, we sort the problems out, but we can never get them to come back regularly because they are so terrified. And then you have a vicious circle, because they come back again and they're in terrible pain."

Frustrating sounds like a good word for it. "It is quite frustrating, but you just can't dictate to people. I just think sometimes people don't realise the value of what we might be telling them. There is a reason for it." In fact, she sounds fairly relaxed about this now, as if this was a battle, with older patients at least, that she has come to accept losing. Her two young daughters, however, are a different matter. And suddenly there is fire in her eyes. "They're sucking their thumbs at the moment," she gasps, "so I'm not too pleased about that."

Curriculum vitae

Pay "I work part-time, three days in the practice, one day in the hospital. Pro-rata, for five days a week, I would say it would be between about £65,000 and £75,000."

Hours 9.30 to 5.30 every day. "But if you wanted to work more, you could. The huge advantage of dentistry is that I can't take my job home."

Best thing Working with people. "One of the satisfying things is when someone does come in and they're terrified, and you're able to turn that around. That's brilliant. And being able to do my surgery. I love doing that."

Worst thing "Wishing you could help more people, and have more of an impact. But I can't change their habits."

Cosmic, by Frank Cottrell Boyce
(Macmillan, £9.99)

The story: Thirteen-year-old Liam wins a trip to the world's most exciting theme park in China, with one snag - he can only go if he pretends to be an adult and persuades one of his friends to go along as his child. Once there he discovers that Infinity Park isn't a theme park at all but a training site for the first children into space. Things rapidly get out of control and Liam winds up as the only "adult" on a spaceship with several kids relying on him to get them back down to Earth.

The author: Frank Cottrell Boyce is a screenwriter and author of two previous novels, Millions and Framed. He has seven children and lives in Liverpool.

What we said: "Funny and engaging and in the end rather moving (though not in a horrible Hollywood 'what have we learned today, children?' kind of way). Having to pretend to be a parent makes Liam realise just what his own parents mean to him. And it also makes him see kids in a new light . . ." - Charlie Higson

Before I Die, by Jenny Downham
(David Fickling, £10.99)

The story: Sixteen-year-old Tessa has incurable leukaemia, but rather than give in, she draws up a wishlist of everything she wants to do before she dies. Sex features, of course, but so does getting her mum and dad back together. Trying to fit it all in does not test just Tessa to the limits, but everyone who comes into contact with her - from her family and her best friend to a store detective who arrests her.

The author: This is the first novel by Londoner Jenny Downham, a mother of two, who puts her chatty style down to her training as an actor specialising in improvised shows, some for children.

What we said: "An affecting and brave novel. Tessa is such a rich character. I really cared about her, didn't like her occasionally, sympathised with her intermittently, rooted for her most of the time, was touched when she opened her heart, didn't want her to go at last while also feeling that strange relief when the time finally came." - Diane Samuels

The Knife of Never Letting Go, by Patrick Ness
(Walker, £12.99)

The story: Girls are banned from Prentisstown, and as the result of a virus, all the men can hear each others' thoughts. The resulting jabber is called the Noise. When Todd finds a pool of silence moving through the marshes, he traces it to a girl and knows he must escape with her. But it's hard being a runaway hero when your pursuers can not only see and track you, but can hear your thoughts too.

The author: Patrick Ness is an American who moved to England nine years ago. He published one adult novel and a short-story collection before turning to children's books with this first of a trilogy.

What we said: "You only have to read the first sentence to see how fantastic it promises to be: 'The first thing you find out when your dog learns to talk is that dogs don't got nothing much to say.' Bog Child, by Siobhan Dowd

The story: When teenager Fergus and his Uncle Tally uncover the half-buried body of a child in 1981, they assume it's a victim of the IRA. As the story of "Mel" unfolds, it's clear that both modern and iron age characters are struggling to unite a fragmented tribe.

The author: Siobhan Dowd was born in London to Irish parents, and worked as a human rights campaigner. She finished writing Bog Child, her second novel, shortly before she died.

What we said: "One of the joys of this book is its willingness to confront big themes . . . Bog Child explores political conflict, personal heroism, human frailty, love and death. Bloss is in the kitchen looking perplexed; her face keeps shifting from tears to elation. With a whisper she confesses to Mrs Cobb: "There was a spot of blood, I thought it was my monthly but there's been no more and I'm feeling strange - changed. I think I've been bit, stung or had."

Old Mrs Coleman, who they all thought was deaf, bellows: "Did you lie with man?"

Bloss blushes. "No. In that way I am pure."

"Maybe it's a tumour," Mrs Coleman says.

"That's not a very nice thing to say," Bea says.

"She's just joking," Mrs Cobb says.

"No I'm not," Mrs Coleman says.

"I feel like things are blooming in me, a world is unfolding, a magic kingdom," Bloss says.

"Have you ever been examined?" Mrs Cobb says.

"Not unless you count playing doctor as a child," Bloss says.

"Well then it would be a miracle, but it wouldn't be the first time - think of the Blessed Virgin Mary," Mrs Coleman says.

"Even if it were true," Bea says, "even if you were preggers, I don't imagine you would be feeling it so soon?"

"Oh but you might," Mrs Cobb says. "With mine I knew the instant it happened, maybe because I'm a cook, but it was like I heard the egg cracking and the little fucker swimming in, and then from every day on it was like fireworks, cells multiplying right and left."

Fiddle walks in and Bloss bursts into tears. "I thought you were off to Cromarty?" Bloss sniffles.

"We left the drummer's drum and had to come back."

Before any more can be said, Polly, the former bride to be, is hurled into the kitchen, having caught her shoe on a step, and crashes into a long wooden table. Mrs Cobb, Bloss, Bea, all grab the edges of the table to keep it from going over. Dishes rattle.

"It's a war zone out there, the forest is strewn with sleeping bodies. I woke up as a hunt from another estate was blowing by. Horses and dogs. I jumped up and started to run as though I was the thing they were chasing," Polly pauses to draw a breath. She smooths her dress.

They all watch. She's still wearing the wedding dress, fitted lavender silk with a shredded train which is like a big puddle around her feet - not surprising she tripped. "I thought I would have spent my wedding night in a connubial king-sized bed, but instead I slept on a bed of pine needles surrounded by wood nymphs."

Fiddle shoots Bloss a look and Bloss turns beet red.

"Where is that woman we're giving a ride to, Miss Dry-clean only?" Fiddle says. "The band wagon's got to be on its way. We came back for the drum and now we've lost her. She said she was running to the loo, but I think it's more like skip to my lou, if you know what I mean."

And no one does know what Fiddle means.

"When I arrived at this haunted hall, the plan was that I'd leave a married woman, but look at me, not only is my life a ruin and the world around me in crumbles, but I'm having some sort of allergic reaction."

She blinks, and for the first time everyone notices that her eyes are very red and swollen. "Some little puck ran round in the night with glow-in-the-dark eye drops, which swelled my eyes closed. I was more than half blind when I woke up and coming back here the first thing I saw was the blurry detail of a woman in the driveway trying to load a donkey into the passenger seat of her car. She kept saying, 'Sit, you pretty boy', and then kissing the donkey on the lips. Do donkeys have lips? 'Sit, you pretty boy', and then a loud kiss. It was quite startling and, even odder, I could have sworn I saw the donkey give her a bit of tongue, a kind of kiss back." Again she stops for a breath. Mrs Cobb hands her a cool damp cloth and motions that she should put it on her eyes. Polly takes the cloth and blots her entire face. "What does it say about me?" she says.

"You're very sensitive, you must have touched something, like a weed, and then rubbed your eyes," Mrs Coleman says.

Polly, not listening, goes on, "Does it imply that I am unlucky in love? Did I blow the one good thing? Am I destined to be an old maid, an also-ran? Do you think I overreacted? Should I have just let him have his way - that is what men expect isn't it, just to have their way? And what was it about a silly photographer that got me so upset? It's a wedding, there should be photographs - shouldn't there?"

"Did you love him?" Bloss asks.

"How would I know," Polly says. "When the thing itself is just before you, it's hard to know what you feel. It's only in its absence that true love blooms."

A shriek of hysterical laughter from the drawing room sends them all skittering out of the kitchen and through the great hall. And there in the drawing room, which is now flooded with morning sun, is Helen, the dry-clean only, hunkered down over the Hinxted Hall house computer - ie the one computer that's left out for the guests to peruse nearby attractions and the evening menu. Helen is there, watching as pictures load from someone's personal thingamajiggy that's plugged into the side port. "I just touched the keyboard thinking I might be able to check my email. The screen came on - and I found this," Helen says, turning the screen so they can all see a full colour image of the donkey and the woman going at it.

"Do you think they Photoshopped the donkey or did that really happen?" Helen asks.

"The image is untouched," says a tousled Jack Mercury sitting up on the sofa - the commotion has disrupted his sleep. The slideshow continues a depraved documentary about how the evening unfolded, ending with a large knife jabbed through the uneaten wedding cake. "Who did that?" Mrs Coleman wants to know. That cake was kept in a special room off the kitchen.

"I confess, it was me," says Jack Mercury, "I was looking for a way to end the piece."

"You mean the magazine is going to run this?" Polly asks.

"They are so excited, I called the editor in the middle of the night and told her everything! In the end I think it may be my best work."

A Conservative MP yesterday revealed that he had been held at gunpoint by soldiers in Colombia who mistook his coffee whitener for cocaine.

Michael Fabricant, 58, the MP for Lichfield and Burntwood, was forced to gulp down several mouthfuls of Coffee-mate to prove he was not carrying drugs as M16 assault rifles and a machine gun were trained on him.

He had been trekking with a friend through mountains near Santa Marta on the Caribbean coast when he was stopped by an armed patrol. Seven soldiers searched his bag and pulled out an unmarked container containing a white substance.

Though Fabricant is fluent in French and German, and has some command of Dutch and Russian, he cannot speak Spanish. "It took some explanation, as I don't speak more than two or three words in Spanish, for them to accept it was Coffee-mate. All they kept shouting at me was 'cocaine, cocaine! Coffee brown, coffee brown'. In their eyes I was carrying raw concentrated cocaine, which I suppose does look quite similar," he said.

Fabricant suggested the soldiers taste the powder themselves, but they refused. "One of them gestured with the butt of his rife for me to sample it instead. I took several mouthfuls and they looked at me as if I was crazy."

Then, he told the BBC yesterday, "they waited a few minutes to see if I collapsed or went delirious and said something completely ridiculous like, I don't know, 'Gordon Brown's got a great personality'. But when I didn't say anything too weird they came to the conclusion that it wasn't cocaine and let me go."

He added: "I was incredibly relieved although, I have to admit, afterwards I felt as sick as a dog."

He was eventually released and allowed to continue his two-week holiday, although shaken by the experience.

"I'm a Conservative MP for a small sleepy city in Staffordshire, I'm not exactly the archetypal cocaine baron. It was hairy stuff. There were seven heavily-armed young men on a foot patrol who approached us as we were walking along a jungle trail."

He added: "I knew Colombia could be a little dangerous, as there is kidnapping and a major drug industry. But I was in a range of mountains north-east of Santa Marta on the coast, which is not generally considered to be drug baron country and is relatively safer than the inland areas."

Lessons had been learned, he said. "I would not wish to unnecessarily cause the risk of a byelection. Next time, I'll make sure the jar is labelled."

Keen to avoid a diplomatic crisis, Fabricant told the BBC yesterday that although Colombian coffee was "really very, very good", he did not trust the local milk, which is why he had brought the coffee whitener with him.

Teachers to vote again on strike over pay

Teachers are to vote again on strike action over pay after executive members of the National Union of Teachers unanimously voted yesterday to proceed with a formal ballot. Christine Blower, NUT acting general secretary, said: "This is a campaign that becomes more relevant with each passing month. With food prices up 40%, utilities up over 30%, with general inflation now running at 5%, teachers, particularly young teachers, are suffering. Refusing teachers a decent salary will have a direct impact on children. The secretary of state must act to halt the spiral of decline in teachers' pay."

DUP in peace talks with loyalist paramilitaries

The Democratic Unionist Party leader, Peter Robinson, has held talks with loyalist paramilitary groups to secure their full support for peace, it was revealed last night. He met the leaderships of the Ulster Defence Association and the Ulster Volunteer Force/Red Hand Commando, who are on ceasefire but have yet to decommission their weapons. Dog has 13 golf balls removed from stomach

A dog had to have 13 golf balls removed from his stomach after eating them during walks. Oscar, a five-year-old black Labrador, was taken to the vet after his owner, Chris Morrison, noticed a rattling noise coming from his pet's stomach. The vet, Bob Hesketh, was stunned: "When I went into his stomach I was expecting one or two balls but they just kept coming." Oscar is thought to have swallowed the balls over a period of months. The dog, who lives with his owner near Pitreavie golf course in Dunfermline, Fife, is said to be in good health - although he now wears a muzzle during walks.

Man held after boy, 3, shot in head with pellet gun

A man was arrested after a three-year-old boy was shot in the head with a pellet gun, police said yesterday. The child was taken to hospital after the incident in Hayes, west London, on Saturday, but was released later the same day. A Metropolitan police spokeswoman said: "As is routine in cases where an injury has occurred to a child and the circumstances need to be properly investigated, a 31-year-old man was arrested at the scene and bailed to return to police on October 4." A London Ambulance spokesman said: "We were called to reports of a shooting. An infant male was taken to hospital."

Former Manchester City trainee Ashley Timms, 22, from Middleton, Greater Manchester, demanded £15,000 from the star, and threatened to publish the images if he was not paid the cash. London-born Defries joins current presenter Andy Akinwolere and fellow newcomer Helen Skelton, 25, for the new series which begins later this month.
